awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Species Interactions in Range Dynamics and Changing Environments: Stochastic Models and Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
The spread of an invasive species is a poorly understood ecological phenomenon, yet it is of great practical importance causing an estimated $120 billion in damages per year.  Current theory largely considers the situation of a single species invading into a stable habitat.  Those models are inadequate to address the realistic situation of invasive species interacting with competitor species as the invasion front moves across the landscape.  They also do not incorporate the fact that habitats themselves can shift on the landscape as a result of climatic and other environmental changes.   For example, rapid movement of habitats toward the poles and higher elevations is a contemporary, global phenomenon.   This research project will develop new theory, backed by experiments with model species in the laboratory, to explain how species invasions are shaped by the presence of competitor species, and the situation of habitats shifting on the landscape.  This work will advance ecological science by providing a stronger theoretical basis for projections of species range shifts driven by invasive species and climate, and provide models useful to land managers, public health officials, and conservation biologists concerned with the spread of invasive species.  This project will provide hands on training and experience to biologists from undergraduate students to postdoctoral scholars, enabling them to become the leaders of the next generation of scientists tackling complex problems in biology.

Important new phenomena for range dynamics emerge when two or more species are considered, and especially given that at the edge of any species range, densities are low, stochasticity must play an important role.  Stochastic models will be developed together with highly replicated, microcosm experiments using a flour beetle model system.  The research will determine 1) how interactions with a resident species modify the range expansion of an invader and its effect on the resident; 2) how species interactions and stochasticity set species ranges in stationary heterogeneous environments; and 3) how species interactions, stochasticity, and moving environments set species ranges and alter spatial community structure.

por.por_cntn:
Why species occur where they do, or what determines their ranges, is a fundamental question in ecology and critical to understanding and predicting how ecological systems respond to environmental change. In this project we investigated how the ranges of species are shaped by the presence of competitors. We developed mathematical models together with highly replicated experiments in the flour beetle model system (genus Tribolium). We completed eight separate experiments yielding the following key findings:

1) Several forms of stochasticity (inherently random biological processes) jointly cause population variability. The outcome of competition is sensitive to the form of stochasticity suggesting current estimates of extinction risk, coexistence and time until competitive exclusion may not be accurate unless relevant forms of stochasticity are included in forecasting models.

2) Interspecific competition and variability in dispersal behavior among individuals results in more variable spatial spread. This variability in spatial spread in a tightly controlled and replicated experimental system points to potential fundamental limitations in forecasting the shifting ranges of species in scenarios such as climate change without considering interspecific interactions and demographic variability in dispersal behavior.

3) Interspecific competition can set up a range boundary between species even in a homogeneous environment. In a key experiment, range expansion of one species ceased shortly after the range boundary of the other species was encountered.

4) At an interspecific range boundary, density-dependent dispersal acts in concert with competition to substantially change the shape of a species' range boundary. This is the first time this phenomenon has been observed.

5) Looking at genomic changes during colonization we found adaptive evolution to be more predictable when populations are first introduced to a novel environment, whereas later during range expansion adaptive evolution is more stochastic. This also points to potential fundamental limits in forecasting the shifting ranges of species.

6) When the environment is moving, such as in the case of climate change, we found that assisted migration can be an effective approach to rescuing populations from extinction, the first experimental demonstration that such an approach can work. This is a significant contribution because this approach can be applied to populations that are experiencing moving environments due to climate change. Nevertheless, we also found the outcome was highly variable, the degree of intervention needed is intensive, and details of the intervention, such as how many individuals to move and where to move them to, need to be precise.

7) For the different experimental tests of analogs to management of invasive species or efforts to maintain species in the face of moving habitat a common important theme was that the outcomes could be highly variable even in a highly controlled laboratory setting.

8) The experimental findings above were backed by predictions from new mathematical models developed for the experimental system. Models were extended to a broader range of scenarios, especially to determine how directed environmental changes interact with stochasticity.

Understanding specifics of species interactions in space that include the role of stochasticity is an important challenge in ecology and population biology. The findings of this project contribute to this understanding by showing that stochasticity in both demographic and genetic factors can play a prominent role and suggest important avenues for future mathematical analysis. At the date of this report, the research resulted in 13 publications in refereed journals with several more in preparation and 13 national and international conference presentations with and by postdoctoral scientists, graduate students and undergraduate students. From this project, our new understanding of population dynamics in a spatial context will provide the scientific underpinning for successful management of natural populations in a changing environment.

Training in interdisciplinary quantitative biology with an emphasis on mathematics, statistics and computation is a national priority. The project was successful in mentoring three postdoctoral scientists at the interface of mathematics, ecology and statistics who have gone on to a faculty position, a university research position (environmental data science) and a position in industry (biological data science). The project was successful in mentoring five graduate students, who received valuable research experience in quantitative biology by being directly involved in experimental design, management of a scientific laboratory, analysis of data and modeling, and in mentoring undergraduate assistants in individual research projects. Graduate students successfully defended PhD theses that included components from this project and progressed to postdoctoral and faculty positions. By being directly involved in research, the project exposed more than 40 undergraduates to experimentation and mathematical analysis in ecology and population biology, thus helping to train future scientists. Many undergraduate students were mentored in independent research projects, including several students that presented at national meetings and one student that published as lead author in a peer reviewed journal. Several undergraduate students coauthored papers. The project also produced a teaching module on species ranges for use in undergraduate introductory ecology classes.
